info.title: Web App Scanning v2
info.description: The Tenable Web App Scanning v2 API serves as a gateway for you to interact with the Tenable Web App Scanning application and enables you to automate the security management for your web applications. You can safely and accurately scan web applications to provide deep visibility into vulnerabilities and context for prioritizing remediations. Use the Tenable Web App Scanning v2 API endpoints to perform CRUD operations on web application scans, launch web application scans, and obtain scan and asset details. For the most up-to-date announcements, subscribe to our [RSS feed](https://feeds.feedburner.com/TenableDeveloperHub) or check the [API Changelog](https://developer.tenable.com/changelog).

tags.name: Attachments
tags.description:
With Tenable Web App Scanning API v2, you can download the attachment files generated by Tenable Web App Scanning plugins during scans. The files provide additional information about identified vulnerabilities.

For background information, see the [Tenable Web App Scanning User Guide](https://docs.tenable.com/vulnerability-management/Content/WebApplicationScanning/GettingStarted/GetStarted.htm).

tags.name: Configurations
tags.description:
With Tenable Web App Scanning configurations, you can maintain reusable settings for running web application scans. Use the API to perform standard CRUD operations on configuration objects.

For background information, see the [Tenable Web App Scanning User Guide](https://docs.tenable.com/vulnerability-management/Content/WebApplicationScanning/GettingStarted/GetStarted.htm).

tags.name: Filters
tags.description:
Some record types in Tenable Web App Scanning support the use of an optional POST body that controls filtering during record retrieval. Before you submit a request containing these parameters, determine which parameters are available for a record type, which fields are available for filtering and in what ways filters parameters can be applied. 

Use the API to list available filters for scan configurations, user templates, asset workbench, vulnerabilities workbench, scan history, and scan finding API operations.

tags.name: Folders
tags.description:
Tenable Web App Scanning provides default folders that automatically organize scans. In addition, you can create custom folders to further organize your scans.

Use the API to create, list, rename, and delete folders.

For background information about scan folders, see [Tenable.io Vulnerability Management User Guide](https://docs.tenable.com/vulnerability-management/Content/Scans/ScanFolders.htm).

tags.name: Plugins
tags.description:
With Tenable Web App Scanning API v2, you can return detailed information for Tenable Web App Scanning plugins, including vulnerability counts by application, OWASP categories, plugin, and severity, number of scanned applications, and scan health.

For background information, see the [Organize Scans by Folder](https://docs.tenable.com/vulnerability-management/Content/WebApplicationScanning/GettingStarted/GetStarted.htm) in the Tenable Web App Scanning User Guide.

tags.name: Scans
tags.description:
With the Tenable Web App Scanning API v2, you can run scans using existing scan configurations, list scans, get scan details, update scan status, and delete scans.

For background information, see the [Tenable Web App Scanning User Guide](https://docs.tenable.com/vulnerability-management/Content/WebApplicationScanning/GettingStarted/GetStarted.htm).

tags.name: Templates
tags.description:
With Tenable Web App Scanning API v2, you can list templates, get template details, create and update user templates based on your organization's Web App Scanning policies, and delete user templates. Templates provide default settings to create scans.

For background information, see the [Tenable-Provided Scan Templates](https://docs.tenable.com/vulnerability-management/Content/WebApplicationScanning/Scans/ScannerTemplates.htm) in the Tenable Web App Scanning User Guide.

tags.name: Vulnerabilities
tags.description:
With the Tenable Web App Scanning API v2, you can get a filtered list of detected vulnerabilities.

For background information, see the [Tenable Web App Scanning User Guide](https://docs.tenable.com/vulnerability-management/Content/WebApplicationScanning/GettingStarted/GetStarted.htm).

get.description:
Returns the specified attachment file for a vulnerability detected by a Tenable Web App Scanning scan. Attachments provide additional details for a detected vulnerability. **Note:** The `transfer-encoding` header value of the response stream is set to `chunked`.
Requires BASIC [16] user permissions and CAN VIEW [16] scan permissions. See [Permissions](doc:permissions).

parameters.name: attachment_id
parameters.description: The UUID of the attachment to download. To determine the UUID of an attachment, use either the [GET /was/v2/vulnerabilities](ref:was-v2-vulns-list) or [GET /was/v2/scans/{scan_id}/vulnerabilities](ref:was-v2-scans-details-vulns) endpoint.

200.description: Returns the specified attachment file as a chunked transfer-encoded stream.

post.description:
Creates a new scan configuration. This operation is asynchronous and returns with an immediate 202. The scan configuration is guaranteed to be created at some point in the immediate future depending on resource load. To track the status of the operation, use the [GET /was/v2/configs/{config_id}/status/{tracking_id}](ref:was-v2-config-status) endpoint. The `config_id` and `tracking_id` can be retrieved from the URI provided in the `Location` header of the `202 Accepted` response.
Requires SCAN MANAGER [40] user permissions and CAN EDIT [64] scan permissions. Alternatively, SCAN OPERATOR [24] user permissions and CAN VIEW [16] scan template (policy) permissions. See [Permissions](doc:permissions).

202.description: The request has successfully been accepted and will be processed.

Location.description: Use the contents of this header appended to the prefix `/was/v2` to execute lookups on the current status of the resource.

400.description: Returned if your request specifies invalid scan configuration parameters.

403.description: Returned if you do not have permissions to create a scan configuration or if you attempt to assign an invalid owner to a scan configuration. For more information, see [Permissions](doc:permissions).

429.description: Returned if you attempt to send too many requests in a specific period of time. For more information, see [Rate Limiting](doc:rate-limiting).

response.value:

put.description:
Updates an existing scan configuration or creates a new scan configuration. This operation is asynchronous and returns with an immediate 202. The scan configuration is guaranteed to be created at some point in the immediate future depending on resource load. To track the status of the operation, use the [GET /was/v2/configs/{config_id}/status/{tracking_id}](ref:was-v2-config-status) endpoint. The `config_id` and `tracking_id` can be retrieved from the URI provided in the `Location` header of the `202 Accepted` response. **Note:** Although this endpoint can be used to create a scan configuration, Tenable recommends the [POST /was/v2/configs](ref:was-v2-config-create) endpoint instead for the creation of scan configurations. To create a scan configuration with this endpoint, you first need to generate a UUID. Tenable recommends the `uuidgen` tool available in most Linux distributions. The `--time` option can be passed to the `uuidgen` tool to ensure that the UUID is unique.
Requires SCAN MANAGER [40] user permissions and CAN EDIT [64] scan permissions. Alternatively, SCAN OPERATOR [24] user permissions and CAN VIEW [16] scan template (policy) permissions. See [Permissions](doc:permissions).

parameters.description: If updating an existing scan configuration, the UUID of the scan configuration you want to update. If creating a new scan configuration, a new UUID generated with a tool like `uuidgen`.
parameters.name: config_id

get.description:
Tracks the current status of a scan configuration creation, update, or upsert process. When creating or updating a scan configuration, this endpoint can be used to determine the current status of the request. You can poll this endpoint using a sensible pause duration between each request until a `completed` or `failed` status is returned. The `config_id` and `tracking_id` can be retrieved from the URI provided in the `Location` header of the `202 Accepted` response from the [POST /was/v2/configs](ref:was-v2-config-create) or [PUT /was/v2/configs/{config_id}](ref:was-v2-config-upsert) request used to create or update the scan configuration.
Requires BASIC [16] user permissions and CAN VIEW [16] scan permissions. See [Permissions](doc:permissions).

parameters.description:
The UUID of the scan configuration.

**Note:** The `config_id` can be retrieved from the URI provided in the `Location` header of the `202 Accepted` response from the [POST /was/v2/configs](ref:was-v2-config-create) or [PUT /was/v2/configs/{config_id}](ref:was-v2-config-upsert) request used to create or update the scan configuration.
parameters.name: config_id

parameters.description:
The tracking UUID for the request you want to retrieve the status for. 

**Note:** The `tracking_id` can be retrieved from the URI provided in the `Location` header of the `202 Accepted` response from the [POST /was/v2/configs](ref:was-v2-config-create) or [PUT /was/v2/configs/{config_id}](ref:was-v2-config-upsert) request used to create or update the scan configuration.
parameters.name: tracking_id

200.description: Returned if the status for the scan configuration was found.

tracking_status.description: The status of the scan creation, update, or upsert process. Possible values are `processing`, `complete`, or `failed`.

value.name: Backup file
value.solution: Do not keep obsolete versions of files under the virtual web server root.
value.description:
A common practice when administering web applications is to create a copy/backup
  of a particular file or directory prior to making any modification to the file.
  Another common practice is to add an extension or change the name of the original
  file to signify that it is a backup (examples include `.bak`, `.orig`, `.backup`,
  etc.).

  During the initial recon stages of an attack, cyber-criminals will attempt to
  locate backup files by adding common extensions onto files already discovered on
  the webserver. By analysing the response headers from the server they are able to
  determine if the backup file exists.
  These backup files can then assist in the compromise of the web application.

  By utilising the same method, scanner was able to discover a possible backup file.

patch.description:
Update the `requested_action` attribute for a scan. The requested action must be valid for the scan's current status. For example, you can stop a scan if it has a status of `running`. Otherwise, Tenable Web App Scanning returns a 409 reponse code. This request creates an asynchronous update job.
Requires SCAN OPERATOR [24] user permissions and CAN EXECUTE [32] scan permissions. See [Permissions](doc:permissions).

parameters.name: scan_id
parameters.description: The UUID of the scan for which you want to update status.

requested_action.description: The action to apply to the scan. The only supported action is `stop`.

findings.name: Missing Referrer Policy
findings.description:
Referrer Policy provides mechanisms to websites to restrict referrer information (sent in the referer header) that browsers will be allowed to add.

No Referrer Policy header or metatag configuration has been detected.
findings.solution: Configure Referrer Policy on your website by adding 'Referrer-Policy' HTTP header or meta tag referrer in HTML.
findings.output: No Referrer-Policy headers or body meta tags were found on http://192.0.2.214/

findings.name: Target Information
findings.description: Publishes the target information of the starting url as evaluated by the scan.

findings.name: Missing Subresource Integrity (SRI)
findings.description:
Subresource Integrity (SRI) is a web security standard that enables browsers to verify that resources hosted by third parties (CDN for example) are delivered without unexpected manipulation.

SRI works by comparing a cryptographic hash declared in the integrity attribute of resource tag (like script) used to fetch the resource and the calculated hash value of this resource.

No SRI have been detected for one or more resources.
findings.solution: Add integrity attribute to the resource tag with prefixed and base64 encoded hash of the resource.

findings.name: Missing 'X-Frame-Options' Header
findings.description:
Clickjacking (User Interface redress attack, UI redress attack, UI redressing) is a malicious technique of tricking a Web user into clicking on something different from what the user perceives they are clicking on, thus potentially revealing confidential information or taking control of their computer while clicking on seemingly innocuous web pages.

The server didn't return an `X-Frame-Options` header which means that this website could be at risk of a clickjacking attack.

The `X-Frame-Options` HTTP response header can be used to indicate whether or not a browser should be allowed to render a page inside a frame or iframe. Sites can use this to avoid clickjacking attacks, by ensuring that their content is not embedded into other sites.
findings.solution: Configure your web server to include an `X-Frame-Options` header.
findings.output: Page http://192.0.2.214/ has no X-Frame-Option header defined

findings.name: Missing 'X-Content-Type-Options' Header
findings.description:
The HTTP 'X-Content-Type-Options' response header prevents the browser from MIME-sniffing a response away from the declared content-type.

The server did not return a correct 'X-Content-Type-Options' header, which means that this website could be at risk of a Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attack.
findings.solution: Configure your web server to include an 'X-Content-Type-Options' header with a value of 'nosniff'.

page_load_wait.description: The time (in milliseconds) that page rendering is delayed during the Selenium authentication process. It is recommended to wait for some time if a page is known to take time before its contents are rendered.

dictionary.description: The type of dictionary to use when testing common and backup files. Possible values are `full` or `limited`.

enable.description: Indicates whether an assessment is enabled (`true`) or disabled (`false`).

element_exclusions.description: Element exclusions prevent scans from interacting with specific page elements (ex. logout buttons or forms) and their children. This setting is available for Scan, Overview, and PCI scan templates.

selector_type.description: Specifies the selector type. DOM elements can be selected based on either text values or CSS attributes. Use `text` for text contents or `attribute` for a CSS key and value pair.

selector.description: If the `selector_type` is `text`, the selector value is a `string` (option 1). If the `selector_type` is `attribute`, the selector value is an object containing one key and value pair (option 2).

oneOf.description: An object containing one key-value pair, where the key is the CSS attribute name and the value is the attribute value. For example: `{"id": "logout"}`

cookies.description: Indicates whether to scan for cookie vulnerabilities (`true`).

ui_forms.description: Indicates whether to scan input and button groups associated with JavaScript code (`true`).

ui_inputs.description: Indicates whether to scan orphan input elements with associated DOM events (`true`).

headers.description: Indicates whether to scan headers for vulnerabilities and insecure configurations (`true`); for example, missing X-Frame-Options.

links.description: Indicates whether to scan links and their parameters in vulnerability checks (`true`).

parameter_names.description: Indicates whether to perform extensive fuzzing of parameter names (`true`).

parameter_values.description: Indicates whether to perform performs extensive fuzzing of parameter values (`true`).

jsons.description: Indicates whether to scan JSON request data (`true`).

xmls.description: Indicates whether to scan XML request data (`true`).

cookies_extensively.description: Indicates whether an assessment is enabled (`true`) or disabled (`false`).

with_raw_payloads.description: Indicates whether parameters should be tested with their raw payloads (`true`) or not (`false`).

with_both_http_methods.description: Indicates if both GET and POST methods should be used during an assessment (`true`) or not (`false`).

with_extra_parameter.description: Indicates whether to test non-existing parameters (`true`) or disabled (`false`).

scan_id.description: The UUID of the scan that detected the vulnerability in the web application.

parent_id.description: The ID of the parent scan in the case of a multi targeted scan.

asset_id.description: The UUID of the asset being scanned.

user_id.description: The UUID of the user that created the scan.

config_id.description: The UUID of the scan configuration.

target.description: The URI of the web application.

created_at.description: An ISO timestamp indicating the date and time when the scan configuration was created, for example, `2018-12-31T13:51:17.243Z`.

updated_at.description: An ISO timestamp indicating the date and time when the scan processing status changed, for example, `2018-12-31T13:51:17.243Z`.

ScanMetadata.description: Summary statistics for the scan results.

queued_urls.description: The number of web application URLs queued for the scan.

crawled_urls.description: The number of web application URLs crawled by the scan.

queued_pages.description: The number of web application pages queued for the scan.

audited_pages.description: The number of pages audited by the scan.

request_count.description: The number of requests the scan made to the target web application.

response_time.description: The average response time (in milliseconds) from the web application.

finalized_children.description: The total number of finalized children if the scan has multiple targets.

total_children.description: The total number of children if the scan has multiple targets.

ScanNote.description: A note describing error conditions the scanner encountered for a given scan.

created_at.description: An ISO timestamp indicating the date and time when the scan was created, for example, `2018-12-31T13:51:17.243Z`.

message.description: The specific message of the note.
message.example: Scan has not been able to connect to the target, or the request to the target URL returns no response.

ScanStatus.description:
The scan status. Values include:
 - abortedTerminated before completion for reason other than a user-requested stop.
 - canceledStopped by a user request.
 - completedCompleted successfully.
 - pendingStart requested but not yet running.
 - processingThe scan has completed but the results are still being processed. The scanner is processing vulnerability findings, attachments, notes, and other metadata.
 - readyScan is ready to be started.
 - runningScan is in progress.
 - stoppingStop requested but not yet stopped.

template_id.description: The UUID of the Tenable-provided template.

name.description: The name of the Tenable-provided template.

description.description: The description of the Tenable-provided template.

plugin_state.description:
Indicates whether the user of the Tenable-provided template has the ability to redefine the settings for the template. Possible values are: 
 - `locked` -- You cannot modify the template. Tenable Web App Scanning rejects any request submitted with settings that differ from the defined template settings.
 - `open` -- You can modify the template without restriction

scanner_types.description:
Indicates which scanners you can use to run scans based on the Tenable-provided template. Possible values are: 
 - `scanner` -- A single scanner running on premises in the client's own infrastructure or environment. 
 - `container_group` -- A group of client scanners running on premises. 
 - `cloud-group` -- A group of managed scanners running within Tenable's cloud infrastructure.

settings.description: The restricted settings for the Tenable-provided template. This is a free-form object as each template can define different parameters for a configuration.

defaults.description: The default settings for this template.

plugins.description: An array of plugins available to the template.

template_id.description: The UUID of the Tenable-provided template on which the user-defined template is based.

name.description: The name of the user-defined template.

description.description: The description for the user-defined template.

owner_id.description: The UUID of the owner of the user-defined template.

settings.description: The restricted settings for the user-defined template. This is a free-form object as each template can define different parameters for a configuration.

name.description: The name of the user-defined template.

description.description: The description for the user-defined template.

owner_id.description: The UUID of the owner of the user-defined template.

permissions.description: The permissions for the user-defined template.

user_template_id.description: The UUID of the user-defined template resource.

container_id.description: The UUID of your organization's Tenable.io instance.

plugin_id.description: The ID of the plugin used to detect the vulnerability.

family.description: The name of the plugin family.

solution.description: Remediation information for the vulnerability targeted by the plugin.
solution.example: Do not keep obsolete versions of files under the virtual web server root.

description.description: An extended description of the vulnerability targeted by the plugin.

synopsis.description: A short summary of the vulnerability targeted by the plugin.

published.description: The publication date of the plugin.

patch_published.description: The date a patch was published to fix the vulnerability targeted by the plugin.

plugin_modified.description: The date when Tenable last modified the plugin.

risk_factor.description:
The risk factor associated with the plugin. Possible values are:
 - low
 - medium
 - high
 - critical. See the `risk_factor` attribute in [Tenable Plugin Attributes](doc:tenable-plugin-attributes).

see_also.description: A reference link discussing the vulnerability targeted by the plugin, typically a vendor security advisory or news article.

cvss3_base_score.description: The CVSSv3 base score for the vulnerability targeted by the plugin (intrinsic and fundamental characteristics of a vulnerability that are constant over time and user environments).

wasc.description: The list of Web Application Security Consortium (WASC) category associated with the vulnerability targeted by the plugin.

cwe.description: The Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) ID for the vulnerability targeted by the plugin.

owasp.description: The Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) category for the vulnerability targeted by the plugin.

family.description: The name of the plugin family.

file_type.description: The MIME type of the attachment file.

config_id.description: The UUID of the scan configuration.

owner_id.description: The UUID of owner of the scan configuration.

scanner_type.description:
Indicates the type of scanner that ran the scan, as configured in the scanner_id parameter of the scan configuration. Possible values are: 
 - `scanner` -- A single scanner running on premises in the client's own infrastructure or environment. 
 - `container_group` -- A group of client scanners running on premises. 
 - `cloud` -- A group of managed scanners running within Tenable's cloud infrastructure.

scanner_instance_id.description: The ID of the scanner (if the `type` is set to `scanner`), or scanner group (if the type is `container_group`) that performs the scan.

name.description: The name of the scan configuration.

description.description: The description of the scan configuration.

target.description: The URL of the target web application.

timeout.description: The time (in milliseconds) that the scanner waits for a response from the web application host.

total.description: The total number of records matching your search criteria.

limit.description: The number of records requested (or the default value if omitted from the request).

offset.description: The starting record you requested (or zero if omitted).

sort.description: An array of objects representing the fields and sort order you specified in the request, which Tenable Web App Scanning used to sort the returned data.

name.description: The field on which Tenable Web App Scanning sorted the results.

order.description: The direction of the sort order. Supported values are `asc` (ascending) and `desc` (descending).

ErrorResponse.description: Tenable Web App Scanning error response.

reasons.description: A list of reasons for the Tenable Web App Scanning error.

items.description: A reason for the Tenable Web App Scanning error, including a code and an extended description.

code.description:
The Tenable Web App Scanning error code. Error code values include:
 - `NOT_FOUND`Returned if Tenable Web App Scanning could not find the resource you specified.
 - `INVALID_ID_FORMAT`Returned if you specify a resource ID in an invalid format.
 - `INVALID_PARAMETER`Returned if you specify an invalid URL parameter.
- `INVALID_JSON_BODY`Returned if you specify invalid JSON in request payload.
 - `DUPLICATE_ENTITY`Returned if you attempt to create a duplicate resource.
 - `NOT_ALLOWED`Returned if Tenable Web App Scanning encounters a stateful conflict, for example, if you attempt to start a scan that is already in progress.
 - `OPERATION_FORBIDDEN`Returned if you do not have sufficient permissions to access a resource or complete a task.

reason.description: The extended description of the cause of the Tenable Web App Scanning error.

InputErrorResponse.description: Tenable Web App Scanning invalid input error response.

code.description: The Tenable Web App Scanning error code. The code `INPUT_FORM_VIOLATION` is returned if your request body contains invalid input.

fields.description: A list of fields that contain invalid input along with a message about the cause of the input error.

items.description: A reason for the Tenable Web App Scanning input error.

field.description: The JSON path of the invalid field.

message_type.description:
The type of input violation. Common input errors include:
 - `VALUE_MUST_BE_SPECIFIED`Returned if a required body parameter is missing.
 - `VALUE_NOT_POSITIVE`Returned if your input contains a negative integer when it should be positive.
 - `VALUE_IS_NEGATIVE`Returned if your input contains a positive integer when it should be negative.
 - `VALUE_CANT_BE_CHANGED`Returned if you attempted to change a value that cannot be changed.
 - `VALUE_MUST_BE_GREATER`Returned if your input contains a value that is smaller than the minimum required lower bound.
 - `FIELD_CANT_BE_ADDED`Returned if your input contains a field that can't be added.
 - `INVALID_TYPE`Returned if your input contains an invalid type (ex. integer or string).
 - `INVALID_FORMAT`Returned if your input contains an invalid format.

value.description: Contains an error message describing the cause of the input validation error.
